MEASURE.NOTICE: The OpenRadiation application, connected with a compatible sensor (see compatible sensors on www.openradiation.org), can be used to measure radioactivity as well as contribute to a citizen science project, by helping to create the OpenRadiation collaborative base, and improve the knowledge of radioactivity in the environment. We suggest that you create a user account at www.openradiation.org, and then configure this account in the application and activate automatic measurement publications (under the settings menu).
MEASURE.TITLE: Radioactivity measurement

MEASURES_HOW_TO.NOTICE: Start the application, search for available sensors and connect a sensor directly from the application. OpenRadiation is a data base aiming to map environmental radioactivity. Select the appropriate measurement mode according to if you take measurements at ground level or on board a plane. To ensure that the data received is homogeneous, comparable and as representative as possible, measurements taken at ground level and published on OpenRadiation must ideally be taken outdoors, if possible at a distance from housing, and with the sensor at a height of approximately 1 m above the ground. The longer the measurement, the more precise the measurement and hence the statistics: an indicator reflects the reliability of the measurement as you take it. After completing the measurement, you can qualify the local environment at ground level (in a rural area, in town) or on board a plane (flight number) and enter additional information before publishing the data. This information can be used to appraise the reliability of the measurement more precisely and to consolidate data.
MEASURES_HOW_TO.TITLE: How can you take measurements?

OPENRADIATION_PROJECT.NOTICE:
OpenRadiation is a collaborative project with the following partners: IFFO-RME - training network in major educational risks -, IRSN - public expert in research and expertise on nuclear and radiological risks -, Planète Sciences – association contributing to the scientific and technical culture of young people - and SORBONNE UNIVERSITE and the fablab PMClab in particular.
Find out more at: www.openradiation.org/en/about-us.
OPENRADIATION_PROJECT.TITLE: The OpenRadiation project

EDITOR.NOTICE:
The OpenRadiation application was mainly developed by IRSN, Sorbonne Université, Agoralogie and ITLink. Do not hesitate to pass on any comments you may wish to make on this application. The application code is published as an open source code.
Check out comprehensive legal texts and contact information at www.openradiation.org/en/legal-notice.

Current version : {{APP_NAME_VERSION}}.
EDITOR.TITLE: Publisher

MEASURES_PRECAUTIONS.NOTICE: The OpenRadiation base is a citizen data base created using unprocessed unfiltered values. OpenRadiation partners cannot be held liable for the values shown and the consequences of any interpretation or use of these values. In addition, the measurements taken with the OpenRadiation application correspond to environmental measurements taken at a given point in time and in specific conditions. These measurements are not necessarily representative of your long-term exposure to ionising radiation.
MEASURES_PRECAUTIONS.TITLE: Precautions for measurements

TERMS_OF_USE.NOTICE:
You are considered to participate in the OpenRadiation collaborative data base if you publish measurements using the smartphone application, either automatically or manually.
The purpose of the OpenRadiation project is to create a collaborative data base on ambient radioactivity levels, therefore all users of the mobile application explicitly accept to share the data recorded, whether published automatically or manually.
The entire OpenRadiation data base is published under the ODC-ODbL (Open Database License). Most of the data submitted is used to create the OpenRadiation data base.
You agree to comply with current legislation, particularly copyright. Using the OpenRadiation data base implies compliance with ethical rules (no insults, respect for privacy, etc.).
OpenRadiation reserves the right to delete any content reported and which fails to comply with the above instructions, without need for a warning.
You can find full details of the conditions of use at the following website address: www.openradiation.org/en/terms-use.
TERMS_OF_USE.TITLE: Terms of use

NOTICE.PART1: If you have a user account at www.openradiation.org, you can enter your account identifiers (user name and password) here. You can then associate your published measurements with your user account: in this way, you will be able to find all of your measurements easily via www.openradiation.org.
NOTICE.PART2: You can also add tags, or a description, to your measurement. Furthermore, by publishing measurements after logging in, you boost the reliability of the OpenRadiation collaborative data base.
NOTICE.PART3: If you have not already done so, we suggest that you create an account at www.openradiation.org, and then configure your account here (synchronization ~5 min).

MAP.NO_CONNECTION: No connection available to display the map

AUTO_PUBLISH_NOTICE.PART1: If you activate automatic measurement publications, your measurements and the associated data will be automatically sent to the OpenRadiation collaborative base, and published under a ODC-ODbL (Open Database License).
AUTO_PUBLISH_NOTICE.PART2: The data transmitted include the data you enter, and information on the model and identifier for the model and/or the telephone used, your user name, and the GPS position at the time of the measurement (see details at www.openradiation.org/en/terms-use).

MEASURES.MESSAGE_ALTITUDE: Tip: high altitude detected, if the measurement was made on board a plane, you should have selected the measurement mode on board a plane

PLANE_MODE_NOTICE.PART1: Cosmic radiation is more important at high altitude, during flights, because they are less attenuated by the atmospheric layer.
PLANE_MODE_NOTICE.PART2: Activation of the on board a plane measurement mode makes it possible to take into account a specific calibration of the sensors for these radiations. On the other hand, if you take measurements at ground level, even in the mountains, choose the ground level measurement mode.

MEASURES.TITLE: Measurement
